WRITING.TITLE: A PLs power to make planetside 2 great for everyone or to ruin it.
WRITING.TEXT: as a platoonlead, you have a lot of respondsability. To attack the right areas, knowing when to retreat and defending key locations while doing the most important thing: making everyone in your platoon have fun. But I've noticed a trend along planetside 2s history that certain outfit platoons drive up a lattice line mercilessly with 48 vs less than 12 enemies. All factions do this, this post is not to say: TRID ZERG CANCER, TTRO ZERG CANCER. But more to point out to everyone who platoonleads that playing the game in a way so that the enemy side has their fun ruined is not good for the games life or to bring in new players. Sure "easy territory captures" is a stragety to do with few defenders, but is it really necerssary to drop an entire platoon of 48 men to take a base defended by less than 12 who most likely aren't even in a squad? For the sake of the future of the game and to make it fun for everyone, I say PLs on all sides should start trying to avoid overpopping fights like the plague.

WRITING.TITLE: Most awkward fight you've had
WRITING.TEXT: The most awkward moment I've had in the field I regularly play on was during a team death match game. I was the last guy alive on our team. With no respawns left, but neither does the enemy. I search slowly around the map with my Thompson held ready, checking corners and the usual peaking spots etc. Ref asks over the speaker if anyone on the enemy team is still alive because no shooting has been happening for 5 minutes. Turns out 1 guy is still alive, about 30 seconds after that. I turn a corner but forget to check my right side, the guy was sitting there holding a Beretta M9 and somehow misses both his shots at a 6 ft distance. Then I turn and aim at him and he just throws his hands in the air and surrenders to avoid being shot at point blank. Then we both laugh at how fucking stupid that just was. This like this is why I love airsoft!

WRITING.TITLE: Who do you prefer to fight?
Rebuff vehicles to pre-CAI levels but reintroduce the timers
WRITING.TEXT: I've been seeing a lot about tanks and balancing on the sub for a while now so I'd throw my own 2 cents in. The reason tanks were supposedly nerfed in killing power against eachother and infantry is because they're so readily available for everyone all the time. This is inpart something you can blame on the ressource system where everyone has infinite ressources and only have to wait a few minutes to afford a new MBT. Back when the game first came out, not only were the ressources fairly limited depending on how much territory you had. But there were also timers to prevent chainpulling. This meant that vehicles were very powerful, but if you took one out of commission that meant that player would not be back with it for quite a while. Obviously the removal of the timers happened and the ressources got based at a flat 50/75 per minute and not based on territory gain. Suddenly there were now hugely powerful vehicles that everyone could chainpull all the time, so people began ripping at either buffing infantry vehicle killing power or nerfing the vehicles. My proposal for a change is to readd the timers, back in the day it was something you could buy certs into to lessen the timer but just give it a flat like 10-15 minutes. If you hadn't certed it back in the day it was 20 minutes before you could pull again. This also means that tanks should be buffed again to be seriously dangerous to one another but also infantry, since infantry seems way to able to counter armor with c4, rocklets, archers, max units, tank mines and plain old rockets and it wouldn't be fun to wait 15 mins cuz you got instagibbed by a single infantry man with c4 costing 1/3 of the tanks cost. Edit: making maxes have a timer again might also be a better choice than increasing their cost.

I think you're trying to get something out of the game that isn't meant to be there. It's simulating a constant never ending sandbox future war with hundreds of people across vast distances. There is no balance in how many vehicles you or your enemy can throw at eachother nor is there a match making system. Planetside 2 is a game of counters and knowing when to use said counters is part of the skill. #8203; The amount of times I see A2G nosegun ESFs dominate medium sized fights because no one on my team besides me is smart enough to pull AA boggles the mind. Same if you're being shelled by tanks from a distance, pull back to the previous base. Pull a tank of your own and go flank the bastards. #8203; Also- Squads and outfits. Have some reliable teammates with you so that you don't get farmed as much because you'll have people you can trust to cover your back and help you get rid of said instagib situations. Getting randomly bolted or HESHed through a doorway on a pointhold hurts a little less when you've been brought back up by a squad medic within 2 seconds.

"This war of mine" Is a game that does something similar, it's a 2d survival game where you are playing as a group of civilians in a besieged city. During the day you clean up the broken house you now call home, build beds and cook food while preparing for the future with things like traps to catch small animals etc. At night you go out to scavenge, in the start you'll get nice easy abandoned homes to loot for food and resources. But those dwindle fast, soon you'll have to make a call about if you should steal from some defenseless people or from more unsavory types like rebels, soldiers or criminals and risk dying. Or even murdering someone to get away safely, which can have severe impacts on your survivors mental health. Overall it's a helluva depressing experience but an important one to give perspective. This game is based on the Siege of Sarajevo which was the longest siege in modern military history (almost 5 years).

I had an incredibly similar moment, not with bayonet though. I had pushed across the road ahead of my squad to scout out the German positions, slowly crawling through the bush with my Garand ready. One guy appears, bang. I shoot him dead. Suddenly 2 of his comrades appear, bang bang. Dead. A grenade gets thrown at me, I manage to get away in time and throw one back. I fire my gun into the forest then reload, when I peak again. 3 more come running towards me and I drop them with a couple shots and narrowly avoid being hit myself. I decide to sod it and get out of this damn forest when I stumble onto an MG gunner and an AT guy who had been laying less than 25 meters to my left, I panic dump my Garand into them and then finally lay down in proper cover with my squad. This entire series of events took around 45-60 seconds and my heart rate was through the fucking roof.

Your narration of what is going on is helpful to people who don't play the game (I assume) It's nice to see you don't edit out your deaths to appear better at the game, something about people who do that irks me wrong. The entire sniping segment was really good. Again, throughout I was kinda bored but I won't fault you for that as it's just not the type of content I watch. But keep up the good work either way!

god damn that sounds bad, the worst experience I've had has only been bad squadleaders ranging from "new" which is excuseable to downright assholes. Altho I will say that sometimes as infantry people need to relax around squadleaders. I had a guy last night constantly yell what we should do tactics wise, would yell the positioning of units and tanks like 4-6 times even after I said "copy" and began placing markers. It's a lot to balance when you gotta ensure there is spawn options, avoid getting shot, shooting back at the eneny, talking to command and other SLs, placing markers, calling out things for your squad members to do AND having this one asshole yell in my ear constantly. Funny story about the PanzerSchreck, it was originally not designed with the shield in mind. Due to it being a big beefy 88mm rocket. Fuel from the rocket was still being expended after it left the tube, so the operator would have to wear protective clothing on their face, body and hands to avoid being burnt to a crisp. Naturally as a soldier, running around in gear like that sucked. So either you'd run around and probably die from exhaustion and low visibility, or you'd die to a tank because you were too slow to get your gear on to safely fire the dedicated anti tank weapon. The troops in the field came up with the idea for the iconic shield we see on it, which was taken notice of and shields were manufactured and shipped out to the troops to then attach to it. This is what happens when you don't test things properly before shipping it into battle, another thing which is very different between Germany and the allies. The allies scrapped so many projects because they didn't hold up, where as the Germans just shipped that shit out regardless of how good it was. \*cough cough\* FERDINAND

Unlikely, because Churchill was massively against peace with Hitler. Even during the Dunkirk crisis. And even if peace with the UK had been achieved, eventually due to oil shortages and ideological desire they would have kicked the hornets nest that is the soviet union. And if they didn't, the soviet union would have attacked them once they were ready. And Germany would have still had it's skull caved in, except in this scenario, the USSR would overrun all of Europe and not just the east.

The impact of the u boats is overhyped, the sheer amount of material flooding in from the US and the british colonies versus what was sunk wasn't enough to change the war. Not to mention that the U-boats had some of the highest casualty rates in the war for their units, it was just kinda left unsupported by the german high command.

There is nothing saying the US wouldn't still have shipped materiel to the soviets even if the UK was not in the war. The soviet union is such a large country that can trade casualties and land at a rate higher than any European power. Not to mention the entire German invasion was planned to only last 6 months, meaning they only prepared supplies and logistics for that amount of time. Meaning their advance was a constant start-stop motion which gave the USSR plenty of time to dig in. Also, the russians did lose moscow to napeoleon. But they burnt it down so that the french army didn't have a place to be for the winter, that is the kind of will to fight that the russian people have in their wars. Especially those that are on their own turf. Remember that Barbarossa was a war of extermination, Hitler had in many speeches and his book laid out that he wanted to exterminate the soviet people and replace them with germans, so the soviets knew this was a literal war of survival and would have fought to the last man.

Yeah but those historians also use sources and citations, so their interpretation can also be completely skewed from reality. Like the book "death traps" is. So I'd say that he cites experts and lectures, not to mention telling people to go watch them themselves for a more in-depth analyses.

Because most of the nations they took over were weaker than Germany, France and England had a bunch of major fuck ups and "last war" syndrome. Not to mention a healthy dose of luck ontop of it. The soviets were caught in the middle of a military transitional period, reeling from Stalins officer purges and that they had advanced into Poland and thus not manning their original defensive lines.

The Tiger models actually do make sense in regard to Germany's oil and manpower shortages. While being on the defensive too. Making more Panzer 4's isn't gonna help if you don't have the fuel run them or men to crew them. So making heavier tanks have a reasoning. Granted, making small upgrades to them all the time even during mid production was a colossal mistake that plagued them from start to finish of the war.

A great example of this is the Panzershreck, people always praise it for it's 88mm lethal anti tank ability. But fail to factor in that the US were the first to field a bazooka. The Germans got inspired by that design but wanted it to be bigger. Problem with it was that bigger rocket meant there was still fuel leaving the rocket as it left the barrel, which would seriously injure or even kill the user if they didn't wear protective equipment. Which running around in during combat is a bitch, or if you have to rapidly put it on as that tank turret is slowly turning towards you is not ideal. That iconic shield we always see it has, was actually a field mock up the troops made to make the Panzershreck actually useful in combat. So they quickly noticed that and began mass producing these shields so they could be fitted onto existing Panzershrecks already in the field.

It's less about engineering than doctrine. The Germans at the time realized that under a 2 front war they'd have to beat the shit out of Russia and just keep the western allies at bay for long enough for them to do so. Hence their trench networks were 100% defensive, meaning they could go all out in the concrete. Permanent facilities and other amenities that made life much easier. The allied trenches however- were always meant as a stop gap. A place to build up forces to attack the enemy line and was never meant to be a permanent solution. Hence why they were so famously awful places to be in. Not to mention that their area was in more low ground so that once they dug deep they'd hit water and turn their entire lines into a mud nightmare that'd eat the feet of the poor sods forced to live in it.

It's mainly about how vehicles interact with infantry that sucks. If you make infantry too strong- you get shit like rocklet rifle LA's. Or if you don't make the base design proper, the tanks will be spamming HESH from a hill into the base and kill random infantry or through doorways. (Looking at you Esamir you dumpsterfire of a continent) Typically vehicles would have enough on their hands if enemies actually attacked sunderes beyond one stray tank or light assault, but as someone who's done both I can say being on foot in the base is way more entertaining. But I also see it as a flaw in how we the playerbase treats the game. I don't agree with the philosophy that you should be able to stick to 1 playstyle only and do everything, a vehicle player should take the choice of either stay outside a base and guard the sundy or leave his tank to go fight in the base. Same in the opposite way, if there is a tank zerg spamming hesh on you and you bitch as infantry, you should stop. Redeploy, grab some tanks yourself and go kill them. I often go out of my way to grab an AP lighting just to get rid of hesh farmers or aircraft (AP best AA). I used to just do nothing back in the day but drive around in my Prowler, I logged in and only did that. But things got pretty boring so when I switched it up with air and infantry and began doing all 3 things as the situation required of me. I became a lot happier with the game. Obviously if you only wanna do 1 thing ever in the game and become the god of that playstyle, sure thing it's what you wanna do. But the game shouldn't be radically changed just because your playstyle might not fit into all situations.

Maybe vehicles are just not supposed to interact in a base attack? Their job is to dominate the field, smash away any resistance and secure the spawn locations for the infantry. Now I wouldn't object to there being more vehicle bases, or if more bases had vehicle points for them to capture and defend. But I don't think that tanks should be able to sit and shell into an enclosed space that is meant for the infantry to fight in. And the infantry shouldn't be the dominant force in an open field fight, once they leave the safety of a structure. A tank should destroy them. I even think they should get a co-axial machine gun because dealing with LA rocklet rifles is honestly one of the most frustrating things I experience in tank. This is what I was getting at with what I saying "one playstyle shouldn't dominate all aspects of the game"- But it seems to differ from yours since you are a vehicle main. Where as I do tanks, air and infantry as the situation requires of me. I'll pull tanks to fight from base to base and other tanks, I'll pull air to shoot down A2G farmers or provide air support for my squad, and I'll run on the point and shoot planetmen if that is where I'm needed most. This way it becomes a combined arms game for me, with each playstyle having a specific role to fill.
Good job, you don't shell the fight and you protect the spawns!

WRITING.TITLE: Remove the weight system entirely from assets
WRITING.TEXT: I made [this post](https://www.reddit.com/r/Planetside/comments/hf0dbt/remove_weight_from_facility_modules/) a few days ago- and after thinking more about it while looking through the things we can build and when I'd possibly use them. It makes no sense to have the weight system for the majority of the items in there. #8203; The reason we see so few ANVILS, Facility modules and other of the more nich #233; items in the game is because of the weight system. Most of these items are highly situational, and they take time to craft ontop of it- but no one is gonna let ANVILs and Facility modules take up valuable space for those rare situations where they are gonna apply them. We've already got several roadblocks with the asset system. Ressource collection time, Asset production time and how many we can have in storage ready to use. If they just tune the amount we can have at a time, like they did with orbital strikes. But remove the weight system- everything else would get way more use out of it. If the Bastion carrier parts had weight to them aswell as the finished Bastion- very few outfits would spend the time building one because it'd just take up more valuable space for Citadel shields, Orbitals and Steel rain. The 3 most useful in the arsenal. So why not do the same for everything else? Reduce the facility modules amount to 5, Citadel shields to 2, Steel rains to 3, Colossus tanks to 2, ANVIL lights to 12, ANVIL mediums to 6, and ANVIL heavies to 3.

Did you even read my post? "If they just tune the amount we can have at a time, like they did with orbital strikes. But remove the weight system- everything else would get way more use out of it. " "Reduce the facility modules amount to 5, Citadel shields to 2, Steel rains to 3, Colossus tanks to 2, ANVIL lights to 12, ANVIL mediums to 6, and ANVIL heavies to 3. " #8203; They're not gonna be able to stockpile 10 orbitals...

We don't need a weight system because we've already got a maximum amount system. The weight system just makes it so that everything else but orbitals, citadel shields and steel rain doesn't get used. Our outfits standard line up is 2 orbitals, 2 citadel shields and 1 Steel rain. These are the most useful that we might need to call on right now. But no one is gonna wait 5 minutes to build a facility module for slightly cheaper vehicles- and they're not gonna have them sit around in storage because 5 weight for something that situational is not worth it. #8203; Removing the weight system and tuning the amount of each thing we can have would make the whole war asset system more used instead of just those 3.

The reason it makes zero sense is because of the overwhelming retardation that is Nazi ideology. They modeled the USSR campaign on the French one because they believed that despite the size and manpower despairity- that the slavs were so inferior that they'd just give up and flee. Hence why they only logistically planned for a 6 month campaign, and not preparing for things like wider soviet railways, dust killing up to 50% of engines in some panzer groups due to the Soviet terrain and the fact that the majority of the army where still on foot or horseback like its fucking 1810. Even had they taken Moscow or the Caucuses oil fields it wouldn't have helped in the end result. It was a war of extermination and the Soviets knew it. So they'd fight to the last man, woman and child rather than surrender.

Yeah- they often overshadow that fact with the even larger amounts of Soviet casualties. But the Soviets suffered around 800 thousand dead by the end of 41- and around 3.3 million captured soldiers from encirclements. Which means that the Germans actually had more dead than the Soviets did by the end of 1941. And then you gotta factor in the fact that losing that amount for the Germans are men and material they cannot afford to lose. Where as the Soviets could more than make up for those losses- to the extent that German high command were confused why there was still resistance when by their own assumptions they had destroyed the Red army multiple times over.

well yeah for caps. But the whole leaderboard shows more than 15 people. Also the post-cap scoreboard still shows the results from the battle that just happened, it only resets if someone else caps the point.
we all capped the point at the same time, of course I believe that because I was there.
To be fair you couldn't pick up buildings as Engineer in TF2 until 2010- 3 years after its release.
